comments.text:
There are beaches in southern California where you are allowed to do 
different things.  This sign simply denotes the ones you can't do at that 
particular beach.  The last one I went to allowed dogs, glass containers, 
alcohol and driving. I believe almost all state beaches have these signs - 
not completely sure though. If I'm going to swim/surf/paddleboard, I really 
don't want to be on a beach that allows glass containers, dogs to poop (and 
they always do), driving, and people trying to put their boats out on the 
water.  When I want to go camping with my dog, camping, drinking and and 
off-roading, I go to the beach that is designated for that.  They can get 
extremely crowded and there are many locals and non-locals alike so this 
helps everyone get to do more of what they want to do.  Sometimes, even the 
same beach has this sign just passing into a new area to designate a change 
in the type of activity/activities for which this area is best utilized.
comments.author: misshitokiri

comments.text:
A lot of people are injured or killed in accidents with tanks.  Almost all 
of these signs are found on training installations and active combat 
installations, not in civilian areas.  Tanks are not slow.  One of the most 
common tanks to run across is the Abrams, which may have a rated top speed 
of 60mph, but can actually go much faster.  You wont hear them coming from 
a mile away.  Although they are loud, the frequencies of sound that travel 
a long ways are usually muffed, and if you yourself are in a military 
vehicle like a HMMWV, that thing is loud as hell inside, also, they're 
camouflaged.  Yeah, they're big, but theyre not that tall.

Finally, and this is the big one, "tank X-ing" signs are usually FOR TANKS, 
designating the places where tracked vehicles are allowed to cross civilian 
roads.  Usually these areas are made of thick concrete instead of the 
tarmac that the rest of the road is made from.

top_comment.text:
Road sign no. 5 is in The Netherlands/Holland.

It's a very common sign and it means that the road isn't very smooth.
Because the country is very flat it is normal all roads are very flat so 
motorist don't expect bumps and holes in the road.
Due the country is very wet (more than 50% is under sealevel) parts of the 
road easely changes shape and there isn't always time to repair the road 
quickly.
For that they place the sign.

The pile of sand may be just a coincidence, or preparation for the coming 
repair.﻿

comments.text:
+Morten Bach Knudsen Perhaps if Hitler had listened to his generals there 
could have been a different outcome, but that obviously didn't happen and 
in fact the whole system of totalitarianism generally makes that highly 
unlikely.  Being an intensely hierarchical system with the supreme leader 
being expected to act by fiat to solve all problems means that voices of 
dissent, however well meaning, are viewed as hostile to the leader's 
infallibility.  Totalitarianism immediately falls into the error of 
employing loads of yes men and murdering dissenting voices as a threat to 
social order.  Similarly the useless yes men are also cast to the winds or 
killed off if they fail.  We can see an example of this with Vladimir Putin 
recently when his Ukranian adventure turned sour on him and he sacked 18 of 
his yes man advisors.  In many ways Hitler represents a large step away 
from Clausewitzian theory in the German Military back to a more Napoleonic 
"Great Captain" model which badly undermined the purpose of the General 
Staff.  In short, Hitler's entire totalitarian model had a massive built in 
catastrophe waiting to happen caused by silencing debate and dissent.  So 
basically, Hitler couldn't really listen to his generals, it cut against 
both his nature, his party aparatus and the entire totalitarian system that 
he had built around himself, and he is not the only dictator fo fall prey 
to this.

top_comment.text:
This is full of stupid explanations for simple instructional signs.
15 - if you're enjoying the beach, you don't want those things. No drunks, 
no broken glass, no noise, no getting hit by baseballs and no stepping in 
dogshit.
14 - The times are simple and the speed limit is clearly timed to match the 
times when the school busses are scheduled to arrive.
13 - I suspect this sign isn't real.
12 - not a dumb sign, a good one
11 - This is a bloody good idea. An easy to repair sign gets damaged rather 
than a dangerous crash into a bridge?
10 - This isn't stupid as the "stop" sign is for "here" and the sign below 
is for the rest of the alleyway
09 - this is pretty obvious but some people are stupid enough to not "get 
it"
06 - Die ahead - photoshopped sign, (and the plural of DIE is DICE, not the 
other way around, Dolan.)
05 - The mound sign was there before the dirt - for the road - coincidence 
joke.
04 - the left lane is likely a fire lane.
03 - Tank crossing - Come on!! Of course there's tanks crossing (near 
military bases), and they are often unlit, or are poorly visible in the 
dark. There are also aircraft crossings, and trains so what makes tanks so 
surprising? In Salisbury, Wiltshire, UK you have road signs warning of live 
fire ranges and explosives......﻿

comments.text:
+jake riley-cross

number 4... is a four lane road. The "X" are the on coming traffic lanes, 
the "up" arrows are the open lanes for that direction.

In the morning most of the traffic is going one way (Probably people going 
to work/school) so they open three lanes in that direction, leaving one 
lane open for on coming traffic.
 
In the afternoon, after work hours, most of the traffic is going the other 
way. People heading back home. So they reverse it. 3 on coming lanes, 1 
lane open the other way.

The rest of the day they split it 2 lanes open each way.

comments.text:
its explaining which lanes are open during peak times.  The X's are the 
lanes that are open in the opposite way.  When theres more traffic, the X's 
are the lanes that have oncoming traffic, the arrows are the lanes that are 
travelling the direction of the sign that you're reading.  If you were 
heading in the direction of oncoming traffic, the X's and arrows would be 
the opposite.  It makes sense, but its confusing at first glance. 
 Basically the lanes on the road change according to the amount of volume. 
 More people heading to work in the morning (eastbound lets say), they have 
3 eastbound lanes open, and only 1 westbound.  Then during normal hours 
they have 2 lanes open each way.  Then at the end of the work day aka rush 
hour, they have 3 lanes open westbound, and 1 lane open eastbound....since 
most of the traffic is going in the opposite direction now.  Does that help 
you understand it?

used, though less frequently than in the past. The form "octopi", as if the 
word were a Latin second-declension noun, is generally considered 
incorrect, but is in fact used, so that it is registered by the 
descriptivist Merriam-Webster 11th Collegiate Dictionary, which lists 
"octopuses" and "octopi", in that order, and Webster's New World College 
Dictionary, which lists plurals in the order: "octopuses", "octopi", and 
"octopodes". The Oxford English Dictionary (2008 Draft Revision) also lists 
"octopuses", "octopi", and "octopodes", in that order, labelling 
"octopodes" as rare and noting that "octopi" derives from the 
misapprehension that octōpus is a second-declension Latin noun and stating 
that, if the word were native to Latin, it would be third declension 
octōpēs (plural: octōpedes) after the pattern of pēs ("foot", plural 
pedēs). The New Oxford American Dictionary (3rd Edition 2010) lists only 
"octopuses" as being the acceptable pluralization, with a usage note 
indicating "octopodes" as being "still occasionally used", and "octopi" as 
being "incorrect".
Related to the word "octopus" are the term "Octopoda" (the taxonomic order 
of cephalopod molluscs that comprises the octopuses) and the adjective 
"octopoid"

A lot of these are nitpicky or just plain misrepresented.  For example:

15: It's a beach. There are a lot of regulations in place to keep it a safe 
and beautiful place to live.  There's no diving so people won't get hurt, 
no vendors because city permits won't allow it, no baseball because they 
don't need anyone beaned in the head by a homer, no motor vehicles on the 
beach, etc.

13: Judging by the fact that this sign was placed on a wooden post, I doubt 
it's a legitimate road sign. It's easy enough to purchase custom road 
signs, and this picture was probably taken to make a funny joke pic on the 
internet.

11: As a past trucker, I find nothing terrible, bad, or silly about this 
sign.  It makes perfect sense. Make an easily repaired sign act as a 
definite warning in place of the difficult to repair bridge (and truck)

10: You're just being a retard with this one. The stop sign is at the point 
where you are entering the alley.

9: Again, not silly, not bad, makes perfect sense. You might not be AWARE 
that you are about to drive past a correctional facility.  It basically 
tells you, 'Hey, there's a correctional facility nearby, so any hitchhikers 
you see may be escaped convicts.'

3: It's a military base.  If it's a Tank Crossing sign that means there 
will be tanks crossing.

1: It's a sign WARNING you that should your car break down, there's a long 
way to go for an emergency phone.  It common to see these kinds of signs on 
long stretches of road that is otherwise undeveloped.

All in all, Dolan, I find you videos rather forced in how you try to find 
humor in one thing or another, and it all seems rather silly, but not in 
the good way.﻿

top_comment.text:
These actually make sense, but they are unusual and funny.  Large bridges 
have the lanes change from on time to another because traffic changes when 
people are going IN to a city in the morning and coming OUT of that city in 
the late afternoon.  The lane not used at all is there for the unexpected 
times of intense travel such as for a big ball game or world fair.  The 
time zones are around schools, but why it can't just always be 25 mph I 
don't know if I'd bother.  Just put in a road parallel so it's not an 
issue.  About Santa Cruz, it just means to enjoy the ocean from a distance 
and keep it clean.  Phone in 100 miles will keep a person from hiking 
expecting to find one.  It should read, "No phone for 100 miles".  
Surprises might be in a park with animalsl  Elk, sand, bison, rabbits. 
elephants, zebras.  Needing to stop for herds. Getting stuck in a herd. 
Getting followed by a herd.﻿

comments.text:
+BartJ583 It's not a typo, it's correct. They saved 1 line and a couple of 
Xs and arrows by formulating it like the way they did. Thus making it (a 
tiny bit) more readable whilst driving.

What it says:
X^^^   6:30 AM - 9:30 PM = 3 Lanes into city, 1 lane out.
XXX^ 3:30 PM - 7:00 PM = 1 Lane into city, 3 lanes out.
XX^^    All other times = 2 Lanes in, 2 lanes out.


What it means:
X^^^  6:30 AM - 3:30 PM = 3 Lanes into city, 1 lane out
XXX^ 3:30 PM - 7:00 PM = 1 lane into city, 3 lanes out
X^^^  7:00 PM - 9:30 PM = 3 Lanes into city, 1 lane out
XX^^  All other times = 2 Lanes in, 2 lanes out.

captions.text:
• From road signs built specifically to
call you a loser, to streets with the worst

name ever imaginable we count 15 whacked out
and crazy-bad messages you will encounter

on the wide open road
15 - Santa Cruz Beach,

• This is a sign from California, in which
you can't drink, smoke, take a pet, drive

a car, light a fire, dive or launch a boat
• All you can do is stand perfectly still,

feel the sand and enjoy what little fun you
can manage to carve out of the experience

• Don't have too much fun though, or you
might come back a few weeks later to find

another white and blue square printed with
the words "no good times"

14 - School Zone,
• Sometimes you forget to slow down during

school hours in the morning and afternoon,
but this particular street is so obsessed

with allotting specific speed restriction
times that it's turned into a goddamn bus

timetable
• And it's not just for one school - but

for three, all over Oakland County
• They claim it's only there because they

don't want to pay for electrical flashers,
but a more likely explanation is that they

outsourced the schedule production to infants
from pre-school

13 - Good Luck,
• It's one thing to produce an indecipherable

hieroglyph of a traffic sign, it's another
to wish would-be motorists a bit of good fortune

on their mission of suicide
• Not to mention the speed limit is remarkably

generous given the sharp and noodly turns
which for no apparent reason sees one turn-off

immediately merge into an earlier turn-off
• It's possible the original creator didn't

realise what their message meant, but it's
equally possible that they're a douchebag

12 - Drink Drive,
• We have a saying in Australia - if you

drink, then drive, you're a bloody idiot
• This here sign doesn't beat around the

bush, drink drive, you're a loser, perhaps
because they ran out of room on the sign,

even though there's clearly enough space to
effectively double the message, add in commas

and additional words - but no, you're a loser
• That'll deter would-be drink n' drivers

out in an open field with no trees or obstacles
around

11 - Bridge Sign,
• This one actually isn't so terrible - a

way to stop truck drivers from ramming their
several ton vehicles into a bridge

• On the downside though, who's to say it
won't scrape the top of the truck, only for

the driver to turn around and say, I'll be
fine, then crash, splat, game over

• Well done, sign - well done
10 - Stop,

• Okay, so here you need to stop in the
alleyway, but you can't STOP stop, just stop

for a moment and then roll on through
• Unless you're a commercial delivery vehicle,

then you can load or unload on the right side
for 30 minutes, and you also need to stop

at the stop sign, but you just can't completely
stop there because then you need to enter

the alley's right side and stop again
• So the law prohibits you from stopping

for longer than a few seconds, but you also
need to wait for oncoming traffic by stopping

so only stop or slow to the point of stopping
otherwise you might have an accident or get

booked
• Or you could, y'know, just want to avoid

this alleyway entirely
9 - Hitchhikers,

• Because, if the words correction facility
area don't already put you on edge, an incredibly

obvious premise should finish the job
• Let's throw up a similar example - gee,

you might think, this lava pit sign is likely
alluding to a dangerous place to drive my

car, but then you find a sign directly below
it that says, caution: fire hot

• I almost wish people WOULD pick up some
deranged psychos just so they could learn

a lesson or two about common sense
8 - Broomrape Lane,

• Do you really need me to explain what's
so wrong about this one? And the ultimate

question: are human being emotionally capable
of choosing to live on a street called Broomrape?

• Or is this just the street for people
who can't read?

7 - Road Surprises,
• Sometimes you get signs so non-specific,

so vague that they should barely even exist
• Strangely enough when you think about

it, this sign actually DOES work to an extent
- it puts you on edge

• What's going to meet you over the next
horizon? A dancing bear conga line, or a nuclear

bomb test site? It's like Christmas, but with
anxiety-inducing danger

6 - Die Sign,
• On first glance, you might think it's

just a simple sign warning you about sudden
cliff drops, or a brief warning about Armageddon

just around the next bend
• It's also possible though that someone

is selling dice up ahead, maybe a little garage
store, and they just happened to use the unfortunate

plural
• Or it might be a sign in front of the

gates of hell, in which case you'll have to
pay a bit of tax

5 - Mound Sign,
• Have you ever had a job so redundant that

instead of clearing away a mound of dirt,
you are instead chosen to build a sign that

warns would-be pedestrians to walk around
it

• Likewise, your image is so poorly drawn
that, instead of a mound of dirt, it literally

resembles a moustache
• That's a clear sign your career is not

going the way you originally planned
4 - Lane Times,

• This is one of the most hotly-debated
signposts, like a trick math equation you

can never get right
• Three lanes are open from 6:30am to 9:30pm,

but two are closed from 3:30pm to 7pm, whereas
all other times only two are open

• So, the top time conflicts with the middle
because from morning to night all three lanes

are open, but then it says two are closed
during that period - does it imply the middle

times supercede the all-day 6:30 till 9:30
lanes, but then should you stick with the

far right lane at peak hour and endure endless
traffic jams?

• And why is the far left lane forever closed?
Who opens a traffic lane that nobody can ever

drive on? Is it lava, or an earthquake canyon,
or a rich guy's private driveway? Why even

mention it on the sign?
3 - Tank Crossing,

• Usually these signs go up if you're about
to hit a road populated by cows, bulls or

hard-to-see animals, but what are the chances
you get blindsided by a fucking tank?

• I mean, they shake the ground beneath
them, AND they're incredibly slow - where

do the tanks even come from? Do they pop out
of a bush? You'd see these things from a mile

off
• Maybe they're implying you're about to

run into an ENEMY tank, and if so you should
give them right of way before they incinerate

your family with some explosive shells
• That's the courteous thing to do

2 - Secret Nuclear Bunker,
• This is a British sign pointing out their

secret nuclear bunker
• No additional information is needed

1 - Emergency Phone
• I mean, why even bother? Clearly the sign

manufacturer knew how far people would have
to walk to reach the phone, and yet they still

placed it here - like it was a joke, like
the idea of someone breaking down in the middle

of this long stretch of road is so unlikely
that it could be a self-writing anecdote

• At the very least they could've left a
bike or scooter here in case of emergencies

- but no, they just assume you're wearing
roller-skate boots, carrying endless supplies

of food and water with a phone to call in
a personal helicopter
